musicalLanguage.description: The wildest piano performance in rock and roll history. Jerry Lee Lewis's boogie-woogie-meets-rock style features a pounding left-hand bass pattern, crashing right-hand chords, and unstoppable energy. This arrangement captures the 12-bar blues-rock feel with walking bass and percussive treble chords.
musicalLanguage.structure: 12-bar blues condensed to 8 bars — C-F-C-G-F-C boogie pattern
keyMoments: Bars 1-2: The driving C major boogie — pounding bass with crashing treble chords
Bars 3-4: F major — the IV chord with the same relentless energy
Bars 7-8: The G-F-C turnaround — classic 12-bar blues resolution at breakneck speed
teachingGoals: Playing at high tempo with control and accuracy
Rock and roll piano technique — percussive, aggressive touch
styleTips: Attack the keys — this is not gentle music. Jerry Lee played like the piano owed him money
The left hand drives everything — it must be rock solid and relentless
Right hand chords should be punched, not pressed — think percussion, not singing
